title: Is Jon Jones next for Daniel Cormier?
text:
Is Jon Jones next for Daniel Cormier? MIKE BOHN, mmajunkie.com 5:36 p.m. EDT October 4, 2015 Jon Jones, left, exchanges kicks with Daniel Cormier, during their UFC light heavyweight title fight Jan. 3 in Las Vegas. (Photo: John Locher / AP) 2 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The UFC light heavyweight title picture is as complex as it’s been in several years after Daniel Cormier ’s successful title defense against Alexander Gustafsson at UFC 192. 
Cormier (17-1 MMA, 6-1 UFC) narrowly escaped the main-event bout with a split-decision victory over Gustafsson (16-4 MMA, 8-4 UFC) in a “Fight of the Year” candidate. 
There’s more than one potential contender that could challenge for the 205-pound title, but UFC President Dana White said he’s not willing to commit a title shot to anyone. 
“I have no idea what I’m going to do,” White said on FOX Sports 1’s UFC 192 post-fight show. “We’ll get back to the office and see what’s next.” 
Among active fighters, Ryan Bader (20-4 MMA, 13-4 UFC) is the top candidate. “The Ultimate Fighter 8” winner defeated Rashad Evans by unanimous decision in UFC 192’s co-headliner for his fifth consecutive victory . 
Bader outworked Evans over the course of three rounds, but was unable to earn the stoppage victory he was searching for. White took notice, and though it was a one-sided performance, the UFC boss indicated it wasn’t quite what he wanted. 
“To tell you the truth, to be honest, I think that Bader had an opportunity when Rashad looked old and slow tonight, and Bader had the opportunity to put the pressure on him and try to finish him,” White said. “Rashad hasn’t fought in a while, Rashad’s had a couple knee surgeries and I don’t know. We’ll see what happens.” 
Bader would likely be up next for a title shot if not for Jon Jones (21-1 MMA, 15-1 UFC), the Ithaca resident and graduate on Union-Endicott High School. The ex-champ’s return looms over the title after he was stripped of the gold in April following his involvement in a hit-and-run accident . 
Jones has not competed since he defeated Cormier at UFC 182 in January, but he recently came to a plea agreement that resulted in 18 months of probation and a number of charity and youth work appearances. 
“Bones” posted a response to Cormier’s victory immediately following UFC 192. He hinted a return to the octagon could take place in the near future. 
Despite the post, however, White would not shed much light on a Jones comeback and said decisions regarding the future of the light heavyweight belt will be made in the coming weeks. 
“Jon has some obligations to handle with his personal situation, and we’ll see how this goes,” White said. “Like I said, I don’t know how this is going to play out.
